diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with leukopenia, autoimmune hemolysis, oral ulcers, and malar rash. Proteinuria indicates kidney involvement, which is also common in SLE.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by features of several autoimmune diseases including SLE. The symptoms mentioned can be found in this disease, particularly in overlapping syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting joints, it can present with systemic symptoms including leukopenia and oral ulcers. Associated with rheumatoid vasculitis, it can occasionally manifest proteinuria and rashes.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disease characterized by dry eyes and mouth. It can also present with leukopenia and has been associated with renal involvement (proteinuria) and vasculitic rashes.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia or neutropenia (leukopenia), often accompanied by other autoimmune symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: While technically part of SLE, when the kidneys are significantly involved (indicated by proteinuria), the condition is specifically classified and treated as lupus nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: This rare disease can cause rash (including a malar rash) and muscle weakness. Though less common, it can associate with leukopenia and renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Undifferentiated Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Represents a condition where there are signs and symptoms of a connective tissue disease like SLE but does not fulfill the criteria of a specific disease. The symptoms listed can appear in this condition.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily a hematological cancer, it can cause autoimmune complications such as autoimmune hemolytic anemia and indirectly cause leukopenia. Autoimmune phenomena can mimic other rheumatologic conditions.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: A group of disorders that destroy blood vessels by inflammation. Depending on the type, it can involve the skin (rashes), kidneys (proteinuria), and blood cells (causing leukopenia), among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the kidneys, joints, and skin, with symptoms like inflammation, pain, and potential organ damage.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder causing chronic inflammation of joints, potentially affecting other organs, causing pain, swelling, and potential loss of joint function.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and valves, potentially leading to systemic infections and affecting multiple organs.

diagnoses.name: Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.description: A kidney disorder that develops a week or two after a strep throat or skin infection, leading to hematuria, proteinuria, and possible hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the blood vessels that can affect any organ, including the kidneys (nephritis), leading to various systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that presents with features of multiple systemic diseases like lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, affecting the skin, joints, kidneys, and heart.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas in multiple organs, including the heart (leading to pericarditis), kidneys, and other organs.

diagnoses.name: Goodpasture's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disease where antibodies attack the lungs and kidneys, leading to bleeding in the lungs and kidney failure.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted by ticks. It can lead to carditis, arthritis, nephritic syndrome, and neurological symptoms if left untreated.

diagnoses.name: Cryoglobulinemia
diagnoses.description: A condition where abnormal proteins in the blood thicken in cold temperatures, leading to restricted blood flow, damaging organs and tissues, including the kidneys and joints.

diagnoses: Viral infection (e.g., dengue fever, chikungunya, Zika virus)
Malignancies such as lymphoma or leukemia
Schizophrenia (in the context of co-occurring autoimmune disorders)
Psychotic Disorder Due to Another Medical Condition
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Drug Reactions or Toxicity (e.g., drug-induced lupus)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with synovitis, discoid rashes, seizures due to neuropsychiatric lupus, pericardial effusion in cardiac involvement, and nephritis indicating kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A disease that shares features with systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis, including synovitis, skin rashes, neuropsychiatric manifestations, and occasionally pericardial effusions.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with Extra-articular Manifestations
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting joints, RA can present with systemic features including pericardial effusions and, rarely, skin manifestations and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting exocrine glands, causing dry eyes and mouth, it can have systemic manifestations, including arthritis (synovitis). Skin and neurological manifestations are less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory condition characterized by muscle weakness and skin rashes. Although it primarily affects skin and muscles, it can have systemic manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by skin thickening, it can involve internal organs, leading to pericardial effusion and renal crisis resembling nephritis.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder that can coexist with other systemic autoimmune diseases, known to cause a wide range of symptoms including skin manifestations, neurological involvement (potentially leading to seizures), and kidney damage.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Rarely, it can present with complications that include embolic phenomena leading to skin manifestations and potentially neurological symptoms including seizures, along with other signs due to the involvement of organs such as the kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: Specifically focusing on the kidney involvement in systemic lupus erythematosus, it emphasizes the significance of nephritis in the context of lupus.

diagnoses.name: Undifferentiated Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A condition that presents with symptoms common to connective tissue diseases but does not fulfill the criteria for a specific diagnosis. Patients can exhibit a variety of symptoms including joint pain, skin rashes, neurologic symptoms, and even kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various organs and tissues of the body. Pleural effusion, autoimmune hemolysis, oral ulcers, and fever are among its common manifestations. Skin involvement can lead to dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Although primarily affecting joints, Rheumatoid Arthritis can have extra-articular manifestations such as pleural effusion and autoimmune hemolysis. It might be rarer for it to cause oral ulcers and dyspigmentation directly, though associated medications or overlapping autoimmune conditions could be contributing factors.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD is an autoimmune disorder that has features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including pleural effusion, fever, and potentially dyspigmentation and autoimmune hemolysis. Oral ulcers can also be present in this condition.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Behçet's disease is a rare autoimmune vasculitis that often presents with oral ulcers as a primary symptom, along with skin manifestations, which might involve dyspigmentation, and less commonly pleural effusion and fever.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disease that might involve the lungs causing pleural effusion, skin causing dyspigmentation, and can also lead to fever. Autoimmune hemolysis and oral ulcers are less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Evans Syndrome is an autoimmune condition characterized by autoimmune hemolysis and other autoimmune phenomena, which might occasionally overlap with symptoms like those described, though the direct association with dyspigmentation and pleural effusion is less clear.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Scleroderma can cause skin changes, including dyspigmentation, and internal organ involvement that could explain pleural effusion. It's less known for causing fever, oral ulcers, or autoimmune hemolysis directly but may be associated with overlapping syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Dermatomyositis presents with muscle weakness and characteristic skin changes, including dyspigmentation. Pleural effusion, fever, and autoimmune phenomena like hemolysis can occur, especially in severe or advanced disease.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.rationale: This vasculitis can cause fever and affect various organs, potentially leading to symptoms such as pleural effusion. Oral ulcers and dermatological changes including dyspigmentation are possible, though autoimmune hemolysis is less typically associated.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Pneumonitis
diagnoses.rationale: As part of the spectrum of SLE manifestations, lupus pneumonitis specifically would indicate lung involvement, potentially leading to pleural effusion. While it's more a subset of SLE symptoms, it highlights the potential severity and specific organ focus of lupus.

diagnoses: Idiopathic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (ITP) with secondary autoimmunity
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Viral Infection (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C)
Sjögren's Syndrome with Central Nervous System (CNS) involvement
Vasculitis, specifically Central Nervous System Vasculitis

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can present with acute pericarditis, fever, nephritis (including lupus nephritis), and go on to cause scarring. Neurological manifestations can include delirium among other neuropsychiatric lupus symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily affecting the heart valves, infectious agents can lead to pericarditis, fever, and renal complications. Immune phenomena can occasionally cause skin changes and neurologic symptoms, including delirium.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.reasoning: This complication of streptococcal infection can cause fever, pericarditis, and nephritis. Though atrophic scarring and delirium are less direct, there could be related skin and neurologic manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: A multi-system inflammatory disease, sarcoidosis can affect the skin leading to scarring, cause fever, pericarditis, and nephritis. Neurosarcoidosis can present with psychiatric symptoms including delirium.

diagnoses.name: Viral Pericarditis
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain viral infections can lead to acute pericarditis and fever. Associated nephritis is rarer but can occur. Delirium could result from severe infection or systemic effects, although atrophic scarring is not a typical feature.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Tuberculosis can cause pericarditis and nephritis, fever, and lead to scarring in various tissues, including the skin. Tuberculous meningitis can manifest with delirium.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: This disease can present similarly to lupus with features like pericarditis, renal involvement, fever, and possible skin manifestations. Neurological involvement can occasionally include symptoms such as delirium.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: Similar to SLE, drug-induced lupus can cause acute pericarditis, fever, nephritis and potentially affect the skin and nervous system, leading to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Uremic Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Severe renal failure can lead to uremia, causing pericarditis, fever due to infection or inflammation, and encephalopathy which may present as delirium. Scarring could be related to long-term complications or treatments.

diagnoses.name: Post-streptococcal Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.reasoning: Following a strep infection, this acute nephritis can occur with associated fever. Though less commonly associated with pericarditis, complex cases can present with a wide array of symptoms. Rash and subsequent scarring are possible, and severe cases could potentially affect mental status.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can damage any part of the body, including skin, joints, and/or organs inside the body.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever, affecting the heart, joints, skin, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.description: Many viruses can cause a combination of these symptoms, including enteroviruses, HIV, and those that cause exanthems like measles or rubella.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A drug-induced condition characterized by extensive rash, fever, lymphadenopathy, hematological abnormalities, and involvement of internal organs.

diagnoses.name: Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare type of inflammatory arthritis that features fevers, rash, and joint pain. It has both adult and juvenile forms.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection transmitted by a tick. Symptoms include fever, headache, rash, and often, abdominal pain, vomiting, and muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the inner lining of your heart chambers and heart valves (endocardium) typically caused by bacteria.

diagnoses.name: Meningococcemia
diagnoses.description: A severe infection of the bloodstream caused by the Neisseria meningitidis bacteria, which can also cause meningitis.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: An acute febrile illness of unknown cause that primarily affects children younger than 5 years. The disease manifests as a vascular inflammatory condition.

diagnoses.name: Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis
diagnoses.description: A rare but aggressive and potentially life-threatening condition, often triggered by viral infections, characterized by fever, pancytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, and hemophagocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various organs and tissues of the body, causing a wide range of symptoms including arthropathy, pericardial effusion, autoimmune hemolysis, and skin changes such as dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for causing joint inflammation and arthropathy, RA can also lead to extra-articular manifestations including pericardial effusion and autoimmune complications.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease causes skin thickening (which can appear as dyspigmentation) and can affect internal organs, potentially leading to pericardial effusion and autoimmune hemolysis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD features symptoms of various autoimmune diseases including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis. Symptoms can include arthropathy, pericardial effusion, and dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash, including dyspigmentation. While more rare, it can also lead to pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A rare autoimmune disorder that combines autoimmune hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, and in some cases, it can be associated with other autoimmune conditions that might lead to symptoms like arthropathy.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: This encompasses a broader range of lupus conditions beyond SLE, including those more limited to the skin which might present with dyspigmentation, but can still have systemic manifestations such as autoimmune hemolysis and potentially pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Adult-Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare inflammatory disease characterized by fever, rash, and arthralgia; it can sometimes lead to pericardial effusion and other serious complications.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder that causes blood clots; it's less commonly known for causing pericardial effusion or other symptoms listed, but it can be associated with other autoimmune conditions that do.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.rationale: A disease that causes swelling of the blood vessels (vasculitis) which can affect various organs. It can occasionally present with symptoms like pericardial effusion and could be associated with conditions leading to hemolysis and joint symptoms.

diagnoses: Viral infections (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis, Dengue Fever)
Evans Syndrome (autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
Rickettsial Diseases (e.g., Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever)

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Cushing's syndrome can cause a wide range of symptoms that overlap with the provided combination, such as osteoporosis, striae (stretch marks usually purplish), and can include conditions leading to hypersensitivity reactions. Eosinophilia and fibrosis may also be associated with complications or underlying causes of Cushing's syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss Syndrome)
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition, which involves inflammation of the blood vessels, can lead to eosinophilia and has been associated with hypersensitivity reactions. The disease can indirectly or directly affect bone health, potentially contributing to osteoporosis and fibrosis in various organs.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation and tissue damage in affected organs. It can lead to osteoporosis, skin changes like striae, hypersensitivity reactions, and eosinophilia. Fibrosis can occur as part of organ damage, particularly in the skin and lungs.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily affecting connective tissue, leading to symptoms orthopedic in nature, Marfan syndrome can also result in skin stretch marks (striae) and predispose individuals to osteoporosis. Although less directly associated with eosinophilia or fibrosis, the wide-reaching effects of Marfan syndrome on connective tissues may lead to related conditions.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Eosinophilic Leukemia
diagnoses.reasoning: This rare condition is characterized by the overproduction of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell. It can lead to tissue damage and fibrosis in various parts of the body, potentially affecting bone health and causing osteoporosis. Hypersensitivity reactions and striae are less central but could be associated with secondary conditions or treatments.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by persistently high levels of eosinophils in the blood without a known cause, this syndrome can cause damage and inflammation to many parts of the body, potentially leading to fibrosis of affected organs. While direct connections to osteoporosis or striae are less obvious, systemic impacts may contribute to these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Löeffler's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This transient respiratory condition is characterized by eosinophilia and can result in pulmonary fibrosis. It is not directly associated with osteoporosis or striae but can be considered in the context of systemic eosinophilic disorders.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.reasoning: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that can form lumps or nodules in multiple organs, sarcoidosis can lead to pulmonary fibrosis. While typically not associated with high eosinophil counts, it can cause skin changes and, less commonly, affect bone density, leading to osteoporosis.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.reasoning: This group of disorders affect connective tissues, primarily the skin, joints, and blood vessel walls, leading to symptoms like stretch marks (striae) and potentially contributing to conditions such as osteoporosis. Direct associations with eosinophilia and fibrosis are rare but can be related to secondary conditions.

diagnoses.name: Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)
diagnoses.reasoning: Following allogeneic tissue transplantation, GVHD can cause a wide range of symptoms, including skin changes (like striae), eosinophilia, and fibrosis of various organs. Indirect effects of the disease or its treatment can lead to osteoporosis.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Allergic rhinitis (as part of hypersensitivity reactions)
Psoriasis (can associate with xerosis and dyshidrotic eczema-like lesions)
Primary Immunodeficiency (related to recurrent infections causing hearing loss and hypersensitivity reactions)
Hypothyroidism (can cause delayed puberty, hearing loss, and skin changes)
Growth hormone deficiency (can lead to delayed puberty and may indirectly affect skin integrity)
Turner syndrome (in females, can lead to hearing loss, delayed puberty, and skin changes)

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.reason: Symptoms including diarrhea and decreased appetite fit the IBS profile. Angioedema can sometimes be associated with it due to allergic reactions.

diagnoses.name: Crohn's Disease
diagnoses.reason: Characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract, causing symptoms such as diarrhea and decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.reason: This autoimmune disorder affected by ingestion of gluten can lead to diarrhea, and decreased appetite. It might also contribute to conditions causing angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.reason: Angioedema is often the result of allergic reactions, which can also lead to symptoms like diarrhea.

diagnoses.name: Food Intolerance
diagnoses.reason: Inability to digest certain foods can lead to diarrhea, decreased appetite, and might trigger angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)
diagnoses.reason: Though not directly causing all symptoms, a severe or spread UTI can lead to discomfort, decreased appetite, and interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Interstitial Cystitis
diagnoses.reason: A chronic condition causing bladder pressure, bladder pain and sometimes pelvic pain, correlating with decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Eczema
diagnoses.reason: This skin condition can cause irritation and inflammation similar to symptoms of Otitis externa and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.reason: This term includes conditions like Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis, both of which can cause diarrhea and decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Certain autoimmune disorders can present with a wide range of symptoms including diarrhea, angioedema, and decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin Deficiency
diagnoses.reasoning: Deficiencies in vitamins such as C, D, and B12 can cause symptoms like easy bruising (Vitamin C), neurological symptoms that might mimic hyperactivity or dysgeusia (B12), and immune system weakening, potentially leading to issues like lymphadenitis and bronchitis.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain autoimmune conditions, such as lupus, can lead to widespread inflammation causing a variety of symptoms including easy bruising and lymphadenitis. Other related conditions might also affect taste or lung health.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.reasoning: Allergies or sensitivities, especially to medications or foods, can manifest in diverse ways including changes in taste (dysgeusia), respiratory symptoms (bronchitis), and sometimes hyper-reactivity of the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Diseases
diagnoses.reasoning: Some infections, including mononucleosis or HIV, can cause generalized symptoms such as lymphadenitis (swollen lymph nodes), easy bruising (due to thrombocytopenia), dysgeusia, and respiratory symptoms like bronchitis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic kidney failure can lead to a buildup of toxins in the body, affecting taste (dysgeusia), causing skin issues like easy bruising, and weakening the immune system, potentially causing bronchitis and lymphadenitis due to decreased ability to fight infections.

diagnoses.name: Liver Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Liver dysfunction can lead to a variety of symptoms including easy bruising (due to impaired production of clotting factors), dysgeusia as a result of altered metabolism, and an elevated risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Cancer
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain cancers, especially those affecting the blood or lymphatic system like leukemia or lymphoma, can cause a wide range of symptoms including easy bruising, lymphadenitis, dysgeusia due to treatment effects or the cancer itself, and more susceptibility to infections like bronchitis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Conditions such as sarcoidosis or Crohn's disease can involve various organ systems causing symptoms like dysgeusia, lymphadenitis, and respiratory issues such as bronchitis due to prolonged inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Endocrine Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Issues with glands, for example, thyroid diseases, can cause a wide array of symptoms including metabolic changes that might manifest as hyperactivity, and indirectly affect immune function.

diagnoses.name: Psychiatric Disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: While not a direct cause of the other symptoms, conditions such as ADHD can account for hyperactivity, and psychiatric conditions can sometimes manifest physically or exacerbate the perception of symptoms like taste changes.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Marfan syndrome can lead to aneurysms, particularly in the aorta, and may also contribute to dyslipidemia. It affects connective tissue, potentially impacting structures involved in obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This group of disorders affects connective tissues, potentially leading to aneurysms, dyslipidemia, and issues with the skin and blood vessels that can indirectly affect sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This diagnosis directly accounts for the obstructive sleep apnea and can be associated with secondary conditions such as dyslipidemia.

diagnoses.name: Lofgren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: A form of sarcoidosis that could explain some of the symptoms like dyslipidemia due to chronic inflammation, though less directly linked to aneurysms or blepharospasm.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reasoning: While more commonly diagnosed in females, it can contribute to dyslipidemia, and indirectly to obstructive sleep apnea through associated obesity.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to dyslipidemia and potentially to sleep apnea due to weight gain and changes in metabolism. Aneurysms are less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Fibromuscular Dysplasia
diagnoses.reasoning: This can lead to aneurysms and might be indirectly linked to obstructive sleep apnea through its vascular impacts, though it's less commonly associated with dyslipidemia and blepharospasm.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: A systemic autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation potentially leading to dyslipidemia and indirectly to aneurysms. Association with sleep apnea is less direct.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily affecting the nervous system, it could theoretically lead to obstructive sleep apnea through muscle weakness. Dyslipidemia may occur as an indirect effect of decreased mobility.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.reasoning: This genetic disorder can lead to tumors along nerves that might indirectly cause obstructive sleep apnea, dyslipidemia due to a sedentary lifestyle, and possibly affect blood vessels, leading to aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that causes inflammation of the blood vessels in your nose, sinuses, throat, lungs, and kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands.
diagnoses.treatment: Observation or anti-inflammatory drugs such as corticosteroids.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine.

diagnoses.name: Crohn's Disease
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory bowel disease that affects the lining of the digestive tract.
diagnoses.treatment: Anti-inflammatory drugs, immune system suppressors, antibiotics, and surgery as a last resort.

diagnoses.name: Upper Respiratory Infection
diagnoses.description: Infections in the upper part of the respiratory system, usually caused by viruses.
diagnoses.treatment: Rest, fluids, and over-the-counter pain relievers and fever reducers.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially serious infectious bacterial disease that mainly affects the lungs.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in infection-fighting cells of the immune system, called lymphocytes.
diagnoses.treatment: Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and stem cell transplant.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic digestive disease where stomach acid or, occasionally, stomach content, flows back into your esophagus.
diagnoses.treatment: Lifestyle changes, medications, and potentially surgery.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: A common disorder that affects the large intestine, causing cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, and diarrhea or constipation, or both.
diagnoses.treatment: Dietary adjustments, fiber supplements, anti-inflammatory drugs, and anticholinergic medications.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body.
diagnoses.treatment: NSAIDs, corticosteroids, antimalarial drugs, and immunosuppressives.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with preserved lung function
Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF)
Primary sleep disorders (e.g., sleep apnea, insomnia)
Chronic Urticaria (as a part of angioedema)
Vitamin Deficiencies (e.g., Vitamin B12, Vitamin C deficiency)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Chronic Infections (e.g., Endocarditis, Hepatitis C, HIV)
Hematologic Conditions (e.g., Leukemias, Lymphomas, Platelet Disorders)
Psychiatric Disorders with Somatic Symptoms (e.g., Depression, Anxiety Disorders)
Squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Polyendocrine Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by the coexistence of several endocrine gland dysfunctions, which can manifest symptoms including hypothyroidism, skin lesions such as warts due to immune dysregulation, and potentially hematologic abnormalities like monocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, which may lead to symptoms such as skin lesions, including warts, eye problems causing difficulty focusing vision, and epistaxis.

diagnoses.name: Aplastic Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition that can lead to monocytosis due to the bone marrow's failure to produce enough blood cells, potentially manifesting in hypothyroidism as part of associated autoimmune disorders and epistaxis due to platelet deficiencies.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelomonocytic Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow, causing increased monocytes (monocytosis), which could theoretically lead to systemic symptoms like hypothyroidism, although more indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can lead to granulomas forming in any organ, including the thyroid (hypothyroidism), eyes (difficulty focusing vision), and skin (warts), with possible hematologic abnormalities such as monocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A common thyroid gland dysfunction that may present with other systemic symptoms or abnormalities (like monocytosis) due to the widespread effects of decreased thyroid hormone levels.

diagnoses.name: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS)
diagnoses.description: Advanced HIV infection can lead to various symptoms including warts due to human papillomavirus (HPV) infections, difficulty focusing vision as a result of opportunistic infections of the eye, monocytosis, and other systemic manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder that can present with skin lesions such as warts, bone lesions that could indirectly affect vision by involvement of the orbit, and can sometimes be associated with endocrine problems including hypothyroidism.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Can cause hematological abnormalities such as monocytosis and may lead to neurological symptoms that could affect vision. In severe, untreated cases, it might indirectly contribute to thyroid dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Severe Acute Malnutrition
diagnoses.description: Though less directly related, severe acute malnutrition can lead to immune system dysfunction manifesting as skin conditions such as warts, and affect overall bodily functions leading to symptoms like epistaxis and, less commonly, hypothyroidism due to overall endocrine system stress.

diagnoses: Blepharospasm as part of a neurodegenerative condition

diagnoses.name: Chronic Pain Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition where patients experience persistent pain that can be from various causes, including past injuries, surgeries, or underlying diseases. This syndrome might lead to hypersensitivity reactions due to the overactive nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions where the immune system mistakenly attacks the body's own cells, which can lead to a variety of symptoms including chronic pain, hypersensitivity reactions, and occasionally hyperthermia as part of inflammatory responses.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow, causing an increase in white blood cells that can lead to symptoms including decreased appetite, epistaxis (nosebleeds), and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune condition that can cause chronic inflammation and pain throughout the body, including the back. Symptoms may also include hypersensitivity reactions and episodic fever (hyperthermia).

diagnoses.name: Infectious Diseases
diagnoses.description: Various infections can cause chronic back pain, hyperthermia, decreased appetite, and hypersensitivity reactions. Examples include tuberculosis or bacterial endocarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that predominantly affects joints causing pain and inflammation. It can also lead to systemic symptoms like decreased appetite and low-grade fever.

diagnoses.name: Ankylosing Spondylitis
diagnoses.description: A type of arthritis that mainly affects the spine, causing chronic back pain and stiffness. Systemic symptoms may include fatigue, decreased appetite, and low-grade fever.

diagnoses.name: Nutritional Deficiencies
diagnoses.description: Deficiencies in vitamins and minerals can lead to decreased appetite, and in severe cases, contribute to chronic pain and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Psychosomatic Disorders
diagnoses.description: These are disorders where psychological stressors manifest as physical symptoms, including chronic pain, decreased appetite, and sometimes hypersensitivity.

diagnoses.name: Hormonal Imbalances
diagnoses.description: Conditions like hyperthyroidism or Addison's disease can cause a variety of symptoms including chronic pain, hypersensitivity reactions, hyperthermia, and decreased appetite.

diagnoses.name: Essential thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A chronic blood disorder characterized by the overproduction of platelets by megakaryocytes in the bone marrow without an apparent cause, leading to thrombocytosis. It can cause complications such as bleeding, thrombosis, chest pain, and erythromelalgia.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that results in the overproduction of red blood cells and often also causes increased levels of white blood cells and platelets. This can lead to symptoms such as headaches, dizziness, chest pain, and an increased risk of thrombosis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic myeloid leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in the blood-forming cells of the bone marrow and invades the blood. It can cause increased levels of platelets and white cells, leading to thrombocytosis, anemia, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A serious bone marrow disorder that disrupts the body's normal production of blood cells, leading to scarring in the bone marrow, anemia, weakness, fatigue, and often thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to various body systems, including the skin, joints, kidneys, blood cells, and heart. Symptoms may include a characteristic butterfly facial rash, migratory patchy macular erythema, chest pain due to pericarditis, and thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. Symptoms can include sores in the mouth and on the genitals, eye inflammation, skin rashes and lesions, and occasionally, vascular problems like thrombosis.

diagnoses.name: Erdheim-Chester Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare form of non-Langerhans cell histiocytosis, characterized by the abnormal multiplication of histiocytes that can infiltrate and damage organs and tissues throughout the body, leading to a wide array of symptoms including pain, erythema, and thrombocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: A disease involving abnormal collections of inflammatory cells that form lumps known as granulomas. The condition can affect multiple organs in the body, including the lungs, skin, and heart, causing a range of symptoms like skin rashes and chest pain.

diagnoses.name: Familial Mediterranean Fever
diagnoses.description: An inherited condition characterized by recurrent episodes of fever and acute inflammation of the membranes lining the abdomen, joints, and lungs. Skin rashes and erysipelas-like erythema can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the small blood vessels that causes them to bleed, leading to a purplish rash often accompanied by abdominal pain, kidney problems, and arthritis. It may occasionally present with thrombocytosis.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Viral Upper Respiratory Tract Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Nasal congestion and rhinorrhea are classic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Similar to viral infection, presents with nasal congestion and rhinorrhea.

diagnoses.name: Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.reasoning: Could explain the abdominal cramps and in some severe cases, hypotension due to dehydration.

diagnoses.name: Overactive Bladder Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly accounts for the symptom of incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause hypotension and, in severe cases, could indirectly relate to abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic Neuropathy
diagnoses.reasoning: Covers a broader spectrum including hypotension and incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection
diagnoses.reasoning: Could explain incontinence and, if severe, the stress on the body might lead to hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Addison's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Chronic insufficiency can present with hypotension, abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.reasoning: Immediate allergic reaction causing hypotension, nasal congestion, and potentially abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Sepsis
diagnoses.reasoning: A severe response to infection causing widespread inflammation, could result in hypotension and abdominal cramps.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Chemical Exposure (e.g., to histamine or sulfites)
Anisakiasis (from ingestion of raw or undercooked fish)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and a feeling of pressure deep inside the ear.

diagnoses.name: Vestibular Schwannoma
diagnoses.description: Also known as acoustic neuroma, this benign tumor on the main nerve leading from the inner ear to the brain can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, vertigo, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Migraine Associated Vertigo
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that may or may not cause a headache but can include vertigo, tinnitus, and hearing problems as symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A brain attack occurring when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, potentially causing symptoms like aphasia, headache, and vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it temporarily blocks blood flow to the brain, causing short, symptom-laden episodes similar to strokes, including vertigo and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include vertigo, hearing loss, and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumors
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growths of cells in the brain that can cause symptoms such as aphasia, headache, and hearing problems depending on the tumor's location.

diagnoses.name: Otosclerosis
diagnoses.description: An abnormal bone growth in the middle ear that can cause hearing loss and sometimes tinnitus or vertigo.

diagnoses.name: Labyrinthitis
diagnoses.description: An inner ear infection causing inflammation of the labyrinth, leading to vertigo, hearing loss, and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Inner Ear Disease
diagnoses.description: When the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the inner ear resulting in progressive hearing loss and dizziness.

diagnoses: Severe Drug Reactions (e.g., Stevens-Johnson Syndrome, Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis)
Stevens-Johnson Syndrome/Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (overlapping conditions, drug reactions)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary kidney involvement
Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) with autoimmune complications
Hemolytic Anemia due to Autoimmune Disorder
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Evans syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with immune thrombocytopenia)
HIV/AIDS associated with thrombocytopenia and anemia
Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Chronic Kidney Disease related to autoimmune disease
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
